patient_information: Age: 20 years Sex: male Country of origin: India Vaccination history: received five doses of anti-rabies vaccine (purified chick embryo cell vaccine) Allergy info: no reported allergies
chief_complaint: Symptoms: fever and quadriparesis Duration: 4 days followed by tingling and ascending paresis over the next month
history_of_present_illness: Timeline: fever for 4 days, followed by tingling and ascending paresis over the next month Key symptoms: fever, tingling, ascending paresis Severity pattern: progressive weakness initially in left leg, subsequently involving all four limbs
exposure_and_epidemiology: Travel history: recent travel to a rabies-endemic country (India) Vector exposure: dog bite on left lower limb Animal exposures: history of dog bite in a rabies-endemic country, presenting with fever and rapidly progressive ascending paresis one month later should elicit a high clinical suspicion of paralytic rabies. Season outbreak context: no reported season or outbreak context
vitals: Blood pressure: 110/70 mmHg Heart rate: 90 beats per minute Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute Temperature: 38.5°C (101.3°F)
labs_and_diagnostics: Blood tests: normal serum electrolytes, renal and liver function tests Cerebrospinal fluid: 52 mg/dL protein (reference: 15–50 mg/dL), 60 mg/dL glucose (reference: 50–75 mg/dL), 340 cells/mm³ (60% polymorphs and 40% lymphocytes) Diagnostic tests: CSF viral RNA by RT-PCR positive, saliva sample collected at admission was positive for rabies viral RNA by RT-PCR
differential_diagnosis: Considered: paralytic rabies Justification: clinical presentation with fever and ascending paresis in a rabies-endemic country, dog bite exposure, and laboratory confirmation of rabies virus
management_and_clinical_course: Treatment: prompt and appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) after an exposure from a suspect rabid animal can prevent rabies in almost 100% of cases. True PEP failures are extremely rare and may occur because of short incubation periods resulting from multiple exposures on highly innervated areas of the body like the face, neck, hands etc. or because of direct inoculation of the virus into nerves. Outcome: the patient died because of a sudden cardiac arrest on the fifth day of hospitalization (9 days post-onset of symptoms)
final_diagnosis: Disease name short: Rabies Confirmation method: positive CSF viral RNA by RT-PCR and saliva sample collected at admission was positive for rabies viral RNA by RT-PCR Evidence: clinical presentation with fever and ascending paresis in a rabies-endemic country, dog bite exposure, and laboratory confirmation of rabies virus
